title: 107_hr1181
content: The Act titled "Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 2001" introduces a new section, 25B, in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to provide a credit for health insurance costs of previously uninsured individuals. The Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 2001 introduces section 25B in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, allowing a tax credit for qualified health insurance coverage paid by individuals for themselves, their spouse, and dependents. The credit is subject to limitations based on monthly coverage amounts. The Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 2001 introduces a tax credit for qualified health insurance coverage, with a monthly limitation of $1,500 per individual and a maximum of 2 individuals per taxpayer. Married individuals have a special rule under this subsection. The Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 2001 introduces a tax credit for qualified health insurance coverage, with a monthly limitation of $1,500 per individual and a maximum of 2 individuals per taxpayer. Married individuals have a special rule under this subsection where only the individual who is married but does not file a joint return and does not live apart from their spouse can be considered for the tax credit. Eligible coverage month is defined as any month where the individual meets certain criteria. The tax credit for qualified health insurance coverage is limited to individuals who were not covered by qualified health insurance for at least a 12-month period after December 31, 2001, and were not eligible for any employer-provided group health plan. The tax credit for qualified health insurance coverage is limited based on adjusted gross income, with the aggregate amount allowed as a credit being reduced by a certain amount determined by the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income. The tax credit for qualified health insurance coverage is limited based on adjusted gross income, with the credit amount reduced by a certain amount determined by the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income, which includes income excluded under specific sections. Any non-multiple of $10 is rounded. The tax credit for qualified health insurance coverage is limited based on adjusted gross income, with the credit amount reduced by a certain amount determined by the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income. Any non-multiple of $10 is rounded to the next lowest $10. The applicable dollar amount is $60,000 for coverage of more than 1 individual and $30,000 for other cases or married individuals filing separately. For tax purposes, marital status is determined under section 7703. Qualified health insurance refers to insurance covering medical care, excluding coverage of excepted benefits. Subsidized coverage does not qualify as qualified health insurance, except for specific circumstances. The term "qualified health insurance" does not include coverage where less than 50 percent of the cost is paid by the taxpayer. No tax credit is allowed for amounts paid under certain government-provided programs such as Medicare, Medicaid, military health programs, veterans' health programs, or the Indian Health Care Improvement Act. Coverage under certain provisions is considered as qualified health insurance for eligibility purposes. No tax credit is allowed if the amount paid for qualified health insurance is used for deductions under specific sections. Dependents are also not eligible for the credit. No credit is allowed if a deduction under section 151 is available to another taxpayer for the same taxable year. Dollar amounts in subsections (b)(2)(A) and (c)(3) are adjusted for inflation for taxable years after 2002. The dollar amount for the cost-of-living adjustment is determined for the taxable year, rounded to the nearest multiple of $100. The table of sections for subpart A of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Code is amended by inserting a new item after section 25A. Section 25B addresses health insurance costs for previously uninsured individuals, with amendments effective for taxable years after December 31, 2001. Section 3 introduces a deduction for qualified health insurance costs for employees and self-employed individuals under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. In general, individuals can deduct the amount paid for qualified health insurance coverage for themselves, their spouse, and dependents. Special rules include not counting this amount towards other deductions and not allowing the deduction for self-employment tax purposes. The deduction for qualified health insurance costs is not considered in an individual's net earnings from self-employment for tax purposes. Amendments have been made to allow this deduction under section 222 of the tax code. The deduction for qualified health insurance costs under section 222 of the tax code applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2001.
